Three earth system models, IPSL-CM5A-MR, MPI-ESM-MR, and NorESM1-M ( Supplementary Table S1) were selected, and the climatic data were downloaded from the CMIP5 website
1 . These data included the mean annual temperature (MAT, °C), mean annual precipitation (MAP, mm/day) and monthly photosynthetically active radiation (mPAR, W ⋅ m -2 ⋅ day -1). mPAR was calculated by SPLASH v1.0 ( Davis et al., 2017) with surface down-welling shortwave radiation (rsds) data. All the climatic data were interpolated into 0.085° × 0.085° with the tools in ANUSPLIN4.4 ( Hutchinson and Xu, 2013). To adjust the bias of future climate models, anomalies were calculated as the differences between the model’s data from 2006 to 2014 and historical data from 2006 to 2014. A time series of future climate was produced by subtracting the anomalies ( Figure 2). This strategy preserved the continuity and stability between the future model’s data and the historical data ( Cramer et al., 2001).
